Faulty's scorecard :-

1) Essential purchase
2) Recommended purchase3) Recommended purchase during a sale
4) Not recommended unless heavily discounted
5) Not even recommended for Steam game collectors

Hold on to your blocks
Over the years we have seen Traveler's Tales take several iconic film properties and give them the LEGO makeover. This strategy has proven to be incredibly successful for both Traveler's Tales and publisher Warner Bros. with LEGO games consistently outselling numerous other big name properties and franchises on the consoles and now to coincide with the release of Jurassic World we get the LEGO version which also happens to contain condensed LEGO versions of the first three movies including, of course, the biggest blockbuster of 2015 so far (until the new Star Wars movie arrives) - Jurassic World

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=480260659
If you are not a fan of this kid-friendly branding exercise, the humor or the simplistic puzzles then I suggest you stop reading now and move along. However, if you happen to enjoy a bit of LEGO mayhem in-between playing your other games, enjoy the sly parodies on display or just happen to be a massive fan of the film franchise then LEGO Jurassic World pays just enough lip service to the originals that should have fans chomping at the bit.

Once again you will find yourself exploring various film scenes from all four of the movies smashing everything in sight to bits while piles of unbuilt LEGO will bounce up and down around you indicating that you can build some sort of device or structure that will enable story progression. While LEGO Jurassic World does incredibly little to tinker with what makes these games so addictive and well loved amongst many, the game mechanics have been slightly overhauled indicating that Traveler's Tales seems to be getting a better handle on the LEGO engine than its previous iterations but like any film licensed product LEGO Jurassic World has the air about it of something that was rushed to the market in order to meet the deadlines determined by the release of the film. Characters repeatedly get stuck in the environment causing the player to have to reboot out of the level and restart it. This can sometimes get incredibly frustrating especially when you are near the end of a level only for this to occur forcing you right back to the beginning. Traveler's Tales have implemented a save feature at certain mid-points in the levels but they very sporadic with some not having any save feature mid-way at all.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=482038193
While I did not experience many bugs throughout my first playthrough, perusing the forums reveals a host of issues that are preventing people from completing the game. While from a production stand point LEGO Jurassic World looks fantastic and is a very strikingly good looking LEGO game; the game does tend to feel a bit more rushed than its predecessors but I suppose that boils down to the fact that most of the scenes in LEGO Jurassic Park mimic the fight and flight scenes from the original movies which does require the action to fly thick and fast. With that being said there is hardly a lull in any of the games 20 chapters (5 across each film) as they move at a breakneck pace. As a huge fan of the franchise I really enjoyed the LEGO treatment given to the films so much so that LEGO Jurassic Park has emerged as my favorite LEGO game to come from TT Games thus far.

Where the game does tend to falter is in the use of its voice overs. Certain scenes are mixed in with the original dialogue from the movies but the movie dialogue sounds tinny and it becomes quite jarring to hear famous lines from the movie sound like they being beamed in from the inside of a soda can compared to the clarity of voice work composed specifically for the game.

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=479304489
LEGO Jurassic World is not going to win over any new fans but for those who enjoy these kinds of games it's a fun and wild romp through all four films and is the perfect game for families playing some couch co-op over the weekend. The humor is as sharp as ever and should have most adults that play it giggling away like children. LEGO Jurassic World gets the all clear in my books. You are free to enter the park.

Introduction
==========
LEGO Jurassic World is the newest installment in the acclaimed LEGO series of games. It covers all 3 Jurassic Park films and the new Jurassic World film, recreating iconic moments from each film in LEGO style. It's been released on nearly every currently available console and PC. Let's dive right into it, shall we?

Gameplay
==========
Being a LEGO game, there are a number of things to do and collect in each level. You play as one of many feature characters from each film, each complete with their own unique special abilities. Some characters are equipped with certain tools, and others have weapons and other miscellaneous abilities. For example, Dr. Grant has a spade which he can use to dig up things, and also a raptor claw, which can be used to cut through obstacles. Nearly everything you see is breakable and rewards you with studs. You can then use these studs to unlock new characters, vehicles, and dinosaurs. There are also Minikits, Gold Bricks, and Amber to collect. Some of these are very cleverly hidden as well, as each stage encourages repeat playthroughs with different unlocked characters to find every secret. All of the fun is playing through each stage and trying to collect as many studs as you can while reliving all the epic moments from the Jurassic Park/World films.

Graphics
==========
As with all LEGO games, the films were recreated nearly entirely out of LEGO blocks and shapes. The characters and dinosaurs are all LEGO built, as well as the environments, vehicles, and other items. Some of the background sets are more realistic pieces, such as landscape views and large clusters of trees and foliage, but for the most part nearly everything is built from LEGOs. reviewText:
LEGOs and dinosaurs: somehow it's taken well over three decades for those two great childhood pastimes to join together in an interactive on-screen adventure. Life finds a way, however, and the two elements are together in a package that may not be the best LEGO-branded adventure, but one that still brings enough to entertain over the course of four fast-but-fun campaigns. The format of this puzzle-focused adventure is as old as dinosaurs -- developer TT Games has used this formula more than 20 times since 2005’s LEGO Star Wars -- but like the pre-historic creatures themselves, there's still a ton of charm.

Anything in the world that's made out of LEGO bricks that isn't one of the 100-plus playable characters can be broken into studs to be spent on bonuses or rebuilt within the environment to progress further in the world. Anyone who's uttered a line in a Jurassic Park movie can be unlocked eventually, from Ian Malcolm and that annoying kid at the raptor dig site to the dino-wrangling, motorbike-riding Owen Grady and, awesomely, Mr. DNA himself. Unlike most LEGO adventures where characters have distinct weapons or superpowers, LEGO Jurassic World's suite of skills are a little more subdued; paleontologists can dig, zoologists aren't afraid to dive into piles of dino-dung, and hunters can set off targets from afar. It's mostly well balanced, though it's weird to see the meek husband-and-wife couple who funded Jurassic Park III's expedition using a grappling hook and gymnastic moves. Also, why are the only characters with scream-based powers women? There’s been plenty of screaming men in Jurassic Park films.

Another distinguishing feature is that LEGO Jurassic World leans far less on combat than most of the previous LEGO-licensed adventures, which makes sense: the movies are mostly about humans trying to avoid dinosaurs. That makes the few fights actually meaningful -- whether it's a throwdown between rival camps in Lost World or the brutal T-rex vs spinosaurus battle in Jurassic Park III, almost every fight has some dramatic flair... unless there are compys involved. Even though the diminutive dinos only appear in the third Jurassic Park film (Edit: oops, the second one too), the species is in every chapter of LEGO Jurassic World, and they never get any less frustrating. They'll swarm in packs, immediately requiring your full attention due to their overpowered health-sapping skills, and their size and speed make them tough to hit. Sometimes there's just one pack nearby, sometimes there's two, and sometimes there's an infinite supply that won't stop attacking you until you cover up the source of the stream. Frankly, I would have just rather had a compy-free experience, since the species makes any stage it infects just a bit less enjoyable than the puzzle-solving, block-breaking norm.

LEGO Jurassic World is an all-inclusive series package, and each of the four movies is broken up into five lightning-fast stages that run two to three segments each. In the space of 30 minutes, I went from saving Lex and Tim to traversing a tree to reach a crashed jeep, to throwing flares in a T-rex's mouth during a tense car chase. Any time I started to get antsy or annoyed about a certain story or set of characters, I knew something I enjoyed would be around the corner. Sure, the gymnastic escape scene at the end of Lost World might have been a bit disappointing, but I was just one level away from seeing Academy Award nominee William H. Macy in LEGO form!

Ironically, the enjoyment I had with the people and creatures of LEGO Jurassic World didn't quite extend to the actual parks. Sure, the levels were mostly a joy, but the overworld is a bit of a mess, especially when I had to explore the islands to find the entrance to a new level. Another weird quirk; while you can play the original Jurassic Park and the newly released Jurassic World right from the start, The Lost World and Jurassic Park III can only be played after completion of the preceding movie's adaption. Fast travel is also iffy, as most of the icons on the map automatically load objectives. Since I wanted to explore the area to find new stages, I'd have to scan each icon until I found the one connected to each section's kiosk, which became so tedious that I'd usually just walk through the interconnected movie hubs to get to my destination. Much like a real theme park, you'll have fun on the attractions but dread getting there.
Jurassic World Video Review

What keeps the compy troubles and overworld woes from becoming too unbearable? That patented LEGO charm. For the first three movies, voice clips are used sparingly and sight gags help add some spice to what should be a line-by-line retellings. Instead of the cowardly investor getting eaten alive on a porta-potty, he stays in the T-Rex's mouth for a few scenes, cleaning the creature's chompers with a toilet brush. When dinosaurs need medical attention they require candy bars and ice pops instead of a tense scene of humans operating on puppets. Also, there's a bit more story being told directly in Jurassic World, so be forewarned that many of the movie's twists will be revealed along the way.
The Verdict

If you have an affinity for any of the four films recapped within, LEGO Jurassic World will be a worthwhile visit. Seeing the series' iconic moments recreated with cute figurines is a treat, and each of the four campaigns is fast-paced enough that completing the entire franchise in its brick-based form will only take roughly seven to eight hours, which is not much longer than the combined film running times (and amounts to brisk mini-campaigns of two hours or less each). Plus, you can tackle this one with a friend and run around as a raptor or Jeff Goldblum. Just beware that there are a few pests inhabiting the island and the line to the best parts of the park may be a bit tough to navigate.

Good
LEGO Jurassic World's puzzles and combat keep up a great pace that get you past annoyances and back to the fun quickly. Annoyances like it doesn't take to long to go through any of the films. In my first 5 hours of play i managed to go through 2 out of the 4 movies.

reviewText:
You know, over the past few months I noticed that there is a distinct decline in the number of licensed movie tie-in games. A couple of years ago, any new super hero flick was accompanied with an eponymous game with dreadful playability. I guess publishers learned a thing or two. I also think that Travelers Tales pretty much takes on any job it gets to fill in the void because they're making games of literally everything as long as it is in Lego.

So the trade is simple. No more bad movie games in exchange for Lego? Seems like a dead giveaway. The Lego games are known for their simple and addictive, but family friendly gameplay and presentation. And since they're basically all running on the same engine; easy to churn out like they're Five Nights at Freddy's. For Jurassic World TT quickly assembled a cast from the entire Jurassic Park series, built overworlds and stages and also made a few lego dinosaurs. Everything fits the mold perfectly and it works. In fact, the formula has been perfected to such a degree it becomes hard to really blame it for being completely unoriginal.

The thing that really sells lego games for me is the character roster. Sometimes over 200 characters can be collected; and the batman series and marvel entry did a good job at making it worthwhile to collect these figurines. However, Jurassic World fails to build on this because you want to play with dinosaurs, yet, you're stuck with people. It's a bit of miss. But if you're looking to play the island adventure from 1993 or 2015, you can't really go wrong with the Lego formula.

It is a okay game. I recommend it, but you have to know that its the same old Lego formula with no innovation whatsoever.

Pros:

+ beautiful graphics
+ love for detail, the world is filled with easter eggs and little nods to the Jurassic Park universe
+ local coop
+ all Jurassic Park movies were recreated
+ various characters that have different abilities, even the smallest staff member is in here
+ they didnt just recreate scenes from the movies, they actually thought out clever new levels, sceneres and additional paths for the heroes to go through, along with a faithful Lego recreation of the beloved movies
+ in the german dub, many voice actors from the original movie reprised their roles, which is fantastic
+ Nvidia 3D TV Play looks awesome. Like its meant to be played in stereoscopic 3D (even cutscenes are 3D)
+ create-your-own-dinosaur
+ replayability if you want all the characters and collectibles

Cons:

- unfortunatley its the same old formula that is being used for EVERY Lego game, destroy everything, pick up coins, build something to unlock new path and repeat, it gets old pretty fast. I was disappointed to see that they didnt even try something new
- picking up coins is a chore, its not particulary neccessary but you still kinda want to see what you can unlock, picking coins up stretches the games lenght by a lot and is just tedious
- breaking all the stuff breaks immersion a little bit, a character is in danger and you gotta hurry, but instead you search slowly through the level what to break to get all the coins.....it slows down the games action scenes by a lot
- coop partners still can hurt each other.....why? there is no reason why you could hit each other in these type of games. Especially when you are playing with a younger kid that smashes the punch button to break all the blocks in the level, comboing the partner to death....its not really coop friendly
- they approached a new open world feel, but ultimatley I whished they would have gone back to a simple level select screen, its tedious to get to the next location and its not clear where you can buy or unlock new things
- the DLCs are terrible! Absolutley cosmetic, but the text makes you belive you get to be a tourist in Jurassic World, but its just a usless skin, the same goes for vehicles, every car feels the same

Overall its a Lego game. Can be fun in coop and looks beautiful. Personally I get tired of the same game with different license, but if you like that definitley get this one too. Its faithful to the movies and universe. A fun ride to enjoy.

reviewText:
Until this game receives a patch, I cannot recommend purchasing this. I'll go over what I liked first:

- The gameplay is exactly what you'd expect from Lego games. Run around, break things, collect studs, solve puzzles, collect bricks, grind your way towards 100% completion. If you've been liking past Lego games, you'll feel right at home with the gameplay here.

- Like all Lego games of this type, it's a very faithful and humorous re-telling of the four movies it covers. There are a lot of humorous moments, and a lot of the cracks it makes at the movies had me laughing a fair bit.

- The graphics are gorgeous. It's colorful and detailed, as you'd expect from Lego games.

- The free roam areas are pretty awesome. Though they are a bit linear, they are full of things to do, and the amount of detail put into them is incredible. There's a free roam map for each movie, allowing for a good amount of variety.

All-in-all, the game itself is great. However, it's held back by an awful amount of bugs. Here's just a few of what I've encountered:

- In one level, a couple of the NPCs simply floated off into the sky for no particular reason.

- A few chase levels have the dinosaur chasing you glitch out, so it disappears, and you're left with nothing chasing you.

- One red brick wouldn't appear until I restarted my game.

- One red brick DID appear before I even attempted to do a puzzle because my AI partner somehow squeezed himself into the final part of the puzzle.

- In a couple of levels, I randomly fell through the floor, falling forever.

- Several times, I got stuck in some of the background, making progress impossible without restarting the level.

- There have been some invisible walls in various areas, particuarly in the green tubes that the small dinos use. Some have literally been impossible to exit because of random invisible walls.

- Some of the raptor jump levers literally will not let you all the way up onto the platforms you're trying to reach, so you have to fight the controls and the background a bit to finally push yourself up.

- In one bonus level where you play as the Indominous Rex, it literally does not appear, so you can't do anything.

- I rescued a Worker In Peril, but it didn't count towards the peril count for some reason, and now the game is acting like she's there when she's not, rendering 100% completion impossible.

- The game has crashed on me several times.

That's just what comes off the top of my head. There may be more I'm forgetting. One or two glitches, I can understand, but this game is literally plain unfinished. The developers rushed this through the gates without even so much as doing a simple bug-test. A lot of these bugs are things you'll find just through doing a normal playthrough of the game.

I've nearly completed the game, but I can't get 100% because of the missing worker. This playthrough has had its moments of fun, but it's also been nothing short of irritating and mind-boggingly tedious.

If and when a patch comes out, I'd say get this game, but until then, save your money.

reviewText:
When they first announced this game, I was hyped to the limit, I mean two of my favourite things are coming together! Jurassic Park and Lego how epic can this be?

Well let's just say, that it's brilliant, it's easily become my 2nd  favourite Lego game of all time (JUST behind Lego Worlds) and my 2nd favourite Jurassic Park game of all time (Which is Jurassic Park Operation Genesis) *WARNING* This review contains spoilers for all 4 movies and the game!

Pros:

VERY faithful to the movies, I mean every scene is recreated (except for one but I'll go after that later) and it's so much fun to run around the islands and story mode.

The Hub worlds are brilliant, they are massive compared to all the other Lego games, and they are so big that they added teleports so you can get around faster! Plus there's a lot to do in the Hub worlds like solve puzzles with characters that you unlock in the story!

Nearly all the characters have a purpose! One of my main complaints in previous Lego games is that some characters feel like they have no use at all, I mean for an example in Lego Star Wars 2 you get R2-D2 and C-3PO who unlock special doors for certain areas, C-3PO cannot attack while R2-D2 can attack enemies and hover for a short while, HOWEVER as soon as you get either 2 characters called IG-88 and 4-LOM, they can access BOTH doors that R2 and C-3 can both use, plus attack and throw bombs, thus making R2 and C-3 useless. Here in Lego Jurassic World however, everyone has a purpose and nobody becomes useless as the game progresses. However Mr DNA and Pachycephalosaurus are kinda OP since Mr DNA makes some characters useless like John Hammond, and Pachycephalosaurus makes Triceratops useless since you can play her anytime you want and jump, while you can play as a baby Triceratops whenever, she can’t jump.

The Dinosaurs are fun to control and finding the ambers which they hide in are fantastic, Minikits also make a return and are fun to collect! Red Bricks make a return and so do Gold Bricks and trust me when I say, all are very addicting to collect.

Making your own Hybrid Dinosaurs is a lot of fun, easy and fun to control, however it’s required to get 100% in the game, so I suggest you make a Raptor with a T-Rex head, because in the game there are areas the T-Rex need to destroy some items with her roar, however she cannot fit into those areas, so if you make a custom Raptor with the T-Rex head, you can go in and destroy those objects.

This game tries to fix all the bad 2 and 3 caused! For an example in Jurassic Park 3 the T-Rex was killed by the Spinosaurus, however this time you can change it! The T-Rex now beats the s*** out of Spinosaurus and lives at the end! Another example is in Jurassic Park 2 they made the story interesting! (Seriously 2 in my eyes was just a bad movie, the ending with the T-Rex attacking the city was the only good thing) Plus they make fun of some of the movie's logic, like in Jurassic Park 2 a guy runs away from a snake while in a waterfall... while a T-Rex is waiting for him outside, and when he runs, the T-Rex comes in and looks at the other characters and give that look to say Did he real do that?" while the others nod.

The biggest pro of this game is it's humour

reviewText:
Ok so this is my second review after Lego Batman 3.  I've played almost all the lego games on multiple platforms but Lego Jurassic World, Pirates of the Caribbean and Batman 2 & 3 were played on my computer with my wired xbox controller.  My review is based on 100% completion of the game and achievements.  I have previously 100% all three Lego Batmans, Pirates of the Carribbean, Lego Movie, and the first Lego Indiana Jones.  With all that said let's get into the meat of this.
The length it took me to finish this game reminds me of some of the earlier Lego games.  Forty hours compared to how long it took me to do Lego Batman 3 and Lego Marvel really isn't much.  I didn't run into some of the same game stopping glitches that others have but that doesn't mean that my game experience was entirely glitch free unfortunately.  There were two very prevalent glitches I ran into.  The first was when a character went to jump a fence quite a few times the character would instead fall through the island and into the abyss never to be seen again.  This usually lead to me having to restart the level, checkpoint or free play depending on what I was doing.  The second one was in one of the bonus levels in Jurassic World.  For whatever reason the dinosaur would just not appear on screen and you couldn't see what you were doing. Sometimes it would magically appear but most of time it wouldn't.  If anyone else is having this problem I waited to do the level until I got the attract studs brick and one of the stud multipliers.  Doesn't really matter if you can see the dinosaur when you have those.  I also had a problem with characters and dinosaurs disappearing and reappearing or just magically ending up in the abyss.  In Gyroscope Valley my character in the gyroscope suddenly disappeared and ended up in the abyss.  I had to start the level over again from the last checkpoint only to be surprised to find that the game hadn't saved my last checkpoint and I had to start over again.  For once it would be nice if Lego would put out a game that didn't have so many glitches.
So why do I still recommend this game?  Well despite some annoying aspects (above named glitches and a very repetitive storyline gameplay) I still had fun with the game mostly for two reasons... the dinosaurs and Mr. DNA.  Yes Mr. DNA is your guide in this game and is also a playable character later on.  He's one you'll want to buy right away because he can hack, acess igen terminals, dig in dino poop (yes characters dig in dino poop), hit targets, track and do the genius equations.  Very valuable especially in free play.  Most dinosaurs are fun to control and can all be customized.  The only one I wasn't fond of was the brachio.  It was big and hard to manuver.  The apo can do what the brachio can and is much smaller.  There are certain things you can't do in free roam/play without the proper dinosaur.   You either need to find the dinosaur's corresponding amber in the levels or customize a dinosaur, only you can't customize a dinosaur with that ability unless you find the dinosaur that has it in the levels first. The biggies are the poison shooting dinosaur and the t. rex from Jurassic Park, the compy from Lost World, either the brachio or the apo, there are a lot of dinos for cracked objects but the one I found worked best was the pachy and the indominous and the swimming dinosaur for parts in Jurassic World.  Some of the other dinosaurs are unnecessary for anything but fun to play around with.
Now as I said above the gameplay is rather repetitive.  Each movie is pretty much set up the same way with quite a few chase sequences.  It was cool at first but got kinda annoying by Jurassic World.  The one kinda cool thing is they actually use dialogue from the movies in the cut scenes.  I'll admit I couldn't always understand what was being said, the movies were shot twenty years ago, but it was still kinda cool hearing Jeff Goldblum's voice coming out of this little lego character.  While the gameplay wasn't always to my liking the story was a fun lego twist on the original.
A few things to note: There are terminals with a blue circle and an I inside spread all over each of the four hubs.  Make sure you stop at each one of these because not all the gold bricks, red bricks, workers in peril will show up on your map unless you do and you'll be flying blind until you get detectors.  Also there is an area in Jurassic Park III where you have to cross in order to get a collectible.  Make sure you have the destroy all objects brick shut off if it's on becuase when you go to jump on the barrels to get across it'll destroy the barrels and you'll end up in the water.  If you forget there is a way to get the barrels back should you make this mistake.  Go to one of the terminals I told you about and use the map to go to another location.  Once there go back to the map and pick to go back to the location.  It will ask if you want to go back at night or day.  Pick the opposite of what it was when you destroyed the barrels.  When you go back the barrels will magically reappear.  Finding the terminals are really important cause it allows to move from place to place and park to park easier so make sure you stop at them all.
The only other comment that I can make on the game are these:
- The graphics are gorgeous.  Best out of all the Lego games.
- The vechicles are slowly becoming easier to control with each game.  Some of the races weren't as bad in this game if you found the right vechicle (Note: buy the gyroscope as soon as it becomes available.  You will need it for some of the hub stuff.)
- While the vechicles are easier to control there was a boat that was absolutely awful.  I had to do that race like twenty times before I got it.  The race with the swimming dinosaur was also a bit tedious.  Lego still needs to work on controlling things in water a bit.
- The little bit of flying was better than previous games but still needs some work
- There was one red brick called compy mode that you can't get without the swimming dinosaur.  It was the last red brick I got when I was already done with the game.  I wish I'd gotten it earlier because it shrunk people to compy size and they started moving really fast.  It was kinda cute.  There was another brick that made everyone talk like they were on helium.  That was kinda cute for awhile too.
While I do recommend the game I also recommend waiting for an update and the price drop as well.  Paying $30 on steam instead of $60 on my PS4 made some of the glitches a little more bearable.  Hopefully there'll be an update soon.  Unto Lego Avengers.

reviewText:
Driving around Isla Nublar in a Gyrosphere, running around Isla Sorna as a Raptor...

With the usual humor of a LEGO game, LEGO Jurassic World brings the four Jurassic Park movies to minifig life. Complete with sound clips from the actual movies for voice overs, you can not only play as Dr. Grant and Dr. Malcom, you hear the actual character voices from the movies. They aren't people immitating the voices, its the actual voices from the movies themselves, so you hear Sam Neil as Dr. Grant and Chris Pratt as Owen Grady. Nice touch.

There are actually 4 hubs in the game, one for each of the Jurassic Park movies. While navigating between the hubs can be tedious at times, I can't really find any fault in the game because of the humor, voice clips, music, and faithful recreations of iconic scenes in LEGO fashion.

Who doesn't love to see Rexy win against the I-Rex or Kelly Malcom owning a Raptor with Gymnastics?

Just like my review of LEGO Marvel Superheroes, I would recommend playing with an XBox controller, as the keyboard controls can feel clunky with it emulating a controller setup.

Lego Jurassic World is yet another yet another yet another LEGO game from Traveller's Tales factory of Lego. Yep, 3D casual platformer based on license. Released in 2015, based on all 4 Jurassic Park movies. It also was released for PS3, PS4, Xbox 360, Xbox One and WiiU. Yes, PC wasn't cut in any way, so everything is good. It also had handheld release for 3DS and Vita, which is your usual lesser, yet different enough that fans might check those out. Maybe.

But first thing you must do before playing this game is to go to options and switch DirectX from 11 to 9. There are too many reports of glitches exclusive to DirectX 11. Even more, it seems that game's saves are tied to DirectX. As in, I seen reports that people were not able to load their old save which they switched from 11 to 9. So yea, do that immeditly.
Those who still have various progress-halting bugs are also recommended to activate V-Sync. It actually fixed some things in old Lego games too.

And yea, like other recent Lego games, it's still is full of various bugs, from crashes to getting stuck in geometry. Personally, it glitched on me on the first launch, where it got stuck in background process and I couldn't end it, so I had to reboot PC. And the final scenes in final level seemed showed me some wonky collision glitches that I was worried that the game is about to just break down like a card construction. Made of lego.

I also recommend using gamepad. Was designed for that. At least it would make circular cranes less annoying, as on gamepad you are supposed to circle analog around.

Anyway, it's yet another Lego game. You know what I mean. Casual. Can't die. Punch things. Hold button to build out of some things you punched. Collect studs. Feel yourself having OCD.
It's good. It's stale.

Nothing much new there. Dinos. Bringing minigames and such from previous Lego titles. I don't think that this one has any new one. Well, maybe repeat input" one for various terminals or such.

reviewText: LEGO Jurassic World is an amazing game, and probably one of the most thought out and well executed LEGO games to date. Unlike some other LEGO games, Jurassic World really does manage to give every main character a completely unique ability which actually makes sense and is enjoyable to use. LEGO Jurrasic World also manages to sucesfully tackle one of the biggest problems LEGO The Movie Video Game had, which was a lack of important characters. Instead of just having all of the levels be played by the same characters over and over again like in LEGO The Movie Video Game, LEGO Jurassic World not only allows the player to control dinosaurs but forces the player to if they want to complete and finish the game, this adds a whole new level of depth to the game and feels very refreshing from the established LEGO video game formula. As with all LEGO video games for the PC, the controls aren't very good and the game plays better if you use a controller. Saying that, the keyboard controlls are noticebly better than the ones in LEGO Marvel Super Heroes. The levels are quite interesting and don't feel too repetitive however the levels for the first and fourth movie are the best and seem to have had the most work put into them. After completing the story, there are many things you can still do, such as complete races, heal dinosaurs and save workers in peril. If you have ever liked a LEGO game before, then LEGO Jurrasic World will be a welcomed and refreshing addition to your Steam game library.

reviewText:
I really wish there was a third option for the reviews, a meh, rather than a recommend or don't recommend.

If you like the lego games, you'll likely enjoy Lego Jurassic World.  It doesn't change the formula in the slightest.  This has its upsides and its downsides because of it.

Pros:
Classic Lego gameplay.  You break stuff, you collect studs, you build things, you solve rudementary puzzles, it's all the classic lego games, just with a jurassic park skin.

Stories are handled rather well.  They (mostly) keep true to the stories, they're presented in a fun way, it's well done.

Classic Lego humor is back.  Lego Marvel was lacking a lot of the classic lego slapstick, this has brought it back.  Characters do silly things, there are plenty of visual gags to laugh at.

You get to play as dinosaurs (some of them, see cons for an explaination)


Cons:
Let's get the big one out of the way, it's glitchy.  This is the glitchiest Lego game I've ever played.  There are puzzles that require raptors to jump on certain things.  I believe there are 5 times you have to do this in the story.  Of the 5 times I tried it, 4 had the raptors getting stuck in midair.  Waiting about 30 seconds finished the animation and I thankfully didn't have to restart any of the levels, but I was dreading each time I'd have to do the raptor jump to progress the game.  I've also had issues with characters getting stuck on objects, compies not being able to get out of tubes, animations glitching out.  It's a glitchy game.  I personally didn't have any gamebreaking glitches, but the ones I experienced certainly had the potential to be gamebreaking.

The voice acting.  This is a problem I've had with every lego game since they started with it in Lego Lord of the Rings.  I don't like the voice acting in lego games to begin with, it works much better in games like Lego Star Wars where the stories are told purely visually.  Lego Jurassic World is the worst of the worst when it comes to voice acting.  Like in the lord of the rings, they decided to use clips of audio taken directly from the movies.  I'm not sure if they were aware of this while making hte game, but sound quality in movies from the 1990s wasn't exactly very good.  It's even more apparent when there are background npcs that have freshly recorded lines form the 2010s.  The difference is instantly noticable, and it's really really badly done.

Strangly anti-death.  In a video game series full of comedic violence and cartoonish death scenes, it's strange to see the lego games go so anti-death with Jurassic Park.  No one dies in the game.  All the people that get eaten don't actually die.  They either get tickled by raptors, or if they do get eaten by a T-Rex, they are vomited out by the end, totally unharmed.  It's very unusually that they'd be this anti-death with such a death filled movie in a series of games that has never been shy about death.  Very strange.

Honestly, it's kind of boring.  The other lego games typically had action based characters, Jedi, Super heroes, Indiana Jones, Magic.  Characters that get into combat based situations, that have special powers, interesting things like this.  Jurassic Park consists of people running away and screaming.  Aside from the main characters, no one is really memorable.  There are a ton of characters to unlock, and only about 15 that you'll actually know.  The unique and cool powers" these characters have consist of screaming to break glass
recommended: and that's really about it.  All of the other powers have already been explored in other lego games

reviewText:
Traveler's Tales' LEGO series, based on various licensed properties, has become somewhat of a staple in many video game collections since its inception with the the 'LEGO Star Wars' games, so after seeing 'Jurassic World' I was ready to go through the LEGO tie-in game, and after a couple of days, I've been left with a dissappointing experience.

There have been many other reviews already talking about the plethora of bugs within the game, and I ran into quite a few myself, two of which halted my progress and forced me to restart the levels I found them on, one of them prevented me from building something because I previously broke some nearby boxes, which is very counterintuitive for a bloody lego game.

However, they also included voice acting for this one, and whilst it's heartwarming to hear Jeff goldblums' laugh (and voice in general) come out of a LEGO figure, the age of the audio become apparent, since it's taken from the original 'Jurassic Park' so the difference in quality between audio from 2015 and 1993 is seen rather easily.

This leads to another problem with the game. It isn't funny. Aside from a chuckle or two I got from the raptors and their shenanigans, none of the humour appealed to me. This is partially to blame on the inclusion of voice acting, since the strength of previous LEGO titles was the physical comedy, it was probably one of the main reasons I loved the LEGO series, but it's been diminished significantly in favour of mediocre verbal comedy, which takes away quite a bit of enjoyment from the game.

The game is strangely anti-death aswell, but I won't dwell too much on that, just know that nodoby dies in LEGO jurassic world, including one character who survived being eaten by being thrown back up a short while later.

However, there is fun to be had in LEGO Jurassic World, the gameplay is as strong as ever, it's still the standard LEGO game affair, smash everything and anything breakable in sight, and attentively searching the levels for the minikits (Most of which are well placed) still manages to be both fun and challenging. A lot of detail has also been put into the open world aspect of it. There's also the option to play as dinosaurs, which is as epic as it sounds!

On the whole though, it's a bit of a mediocre experience for me, but would I recommend the game? Short answer: Probably not. If you love the other LEGO games, you'll probably like this one (If it works for you), however, if your new to the LEGO games, don't buy this one. Get 'LEGO Star Wars: The Complete Saga' Instead, It's not as buggy, cheaper, funnier and is based on a better film franchise.

TL;DR: Dissappointing. Weak humour, but still has good lego collectathon style gameplay. Not even Jeff Goldblum and playing as a T-Rex could save this one.

Final Score: 6/10

(Sence i encountered a rather gamebreaking bug in world 2 that freezes the game up trying to move between worlds or enter certain missions, i have to retract my recommendation for this game.)

This game is really fun and has its funny moments.

Sure some of the movies may have been garbage, but this game kind of blends the games into a really really good mixed cake of tasty dinosaur rompage...plus theres quite a few minigames where you rampage around as a T-rex...how is that not cool?

reviewText:
Though I love Jurassic Park, it's impossible to recommend this game considering how absolutely broken it is. The first issue came when I couldn't even enter the main menu due to the game not registering any keys or mouse clicks to enter. After ctrl-alt-deleting to exit and then restarting the game, it allowed me to enter. From this point on EVERY one of the dozen or so times I tried to start the game required a failed attempt into a restart to be able to play.

Once I got into the game it was fun, though simplistic. I paused it for a moment, and when I tried to unpause it was frozen again. Restart, play, freeze, restart, play, freeze. I did it on purpose a few times just to see if what I thought was happening was happening: you've got about a 50% chance of the game freezing up on you whenever you pause it. Then it takes two more restarts to get back in. And the cutscenes weren't skipabble either, though this may've been because the game was counting this as my 'first time through' because it didn't autosave. I finally made it to a save point (do games even still have these?) and, just like on the pause menu, it crashed.

Not only this, but nowhere does the game state that it has absolutely NO mouse support. It's a simplistic enough game, but not being able to implement such an easily accessible and vital feature reeks of either laziness or incompetence. It's prety much a direct console port with little to no care put into it.

It was a mistake buying this on release, I really should've waited for a sale a couple months from now, but my excitement really got the better of me. I'm going to be refunding Jurassic World immediately.

This new lego game is very fun and stays pretty well in line with the material it is based off of. The hub world is much more easily navigated than some of the previous games and seems very approachable because it is split up. In lego marvel superheroes the hub world felt overwhelming at times because it was saturated with content, but the multiple jurassic park hubs are well balanced and have purposeful side tasks that make sense for that part of the park. The game's interpretation of the story is still in the fun style of lego and is light hearted, never as violent as the films were. There are quite a few goals that the game presents but the one I found most fun was to collect the amber brick in each level, unlocking dinosaurs to customize and play as in certain park areas. There is a nice variety of dinosaurs to be unlocked and the movie star dinos are almost all in the lineup of twenty. Each unlockable dinosaur has different abilities or aspects that make it different and worth collecting all of them. Lego Jurassic World is now definitely in my top three lego games, alongside the original star wars and indiana jones lego games. It brings some new ideas to the table and displays jurassic park in a creative fun way. If you are a fan of lego games, be sure to play this game.

At the core t is still just one more lego game: You play through the story, unlock characters, vehicles, minikits, blocks and all that jazz. Oh yes and there are dinosauruses mixed in. For a jurassic park fan this'll be a blast, but sometimes the story skips a bit and might feel a tad confusing if the movies are not fresh in your mind.

Some improvements have been made since Marvel. (I haven't played Batman and refuse to play Hobbit since it is unfinished, so I can't really comment on any improvements regarding those titles.) Many stages allow loads of backtracking and in Free Play you can start from any checkpoint, which is HUGE when trying to find those last pesky minikits. Also The Hub is interesting and well thought.

In the end it is basically the same concept as any other lego game. But that is not a bad thing in my book.

Just be aware that people are reporting bugs. In my 100% playthrough I once fell through the world (but respawned quickly after that) and once a character just kept running to a wall and did not respond to the controls. Other than that I had no big problems.

♥If you've played any of the recent Lego games, you know exactly what you're getting into: solidly designed platforming amidst a world made of bricks. Combat takes a back seat to simple problem solving as you find ways to clear environmental obstacles, which often takes the form of building new things out of loose bricks that are lying around. Cooperation is also encouraged thanks to hop-in multiplayer and a cavalcade of characters to take control of, each of which has special abilities you need to use to progress through the game. Tying everything together are hub worlds that you can wander around in and collect red bricks (which unlock the ability to buy certain perks) and gold ones (which unlock certain optional sections once you have enough of them), so you get a little bit of structural variety as you progress, which is a nice counterpoint to the very linear levels proper.The different abilities are simply keys to unlock progress or secrets. You never get the chance to noodle around with the mechanics or improvise since there's always just one solution to every obstacle the game puts in your way. Another unfortunate side effect of this approach is the fact that the things you're doing in-game aren't nearly as interesting as the things your in-game avatar is doing. She might be performing a high-pitched scream to break some glass in your way or building a giant replica of a hot dog to distract a rampaging dino. In reality, you're moving from one spot in a level to another, where you activate a thing that lets you move on to the next thing, and so on. Granted, this is the baseline for how game levels are built at their core, but Traveller's Tales does nothing to hide this pattern, nor does it add any complexity to how scenarios play out. It's all focused on throwing exactly one obstacle at you at a time with very little stopping you in between. Lego Jurassic World absolutely has its heart in the right place. Every scene is injected with the now-trademark Lego sense of humor. Events like seeing Chris Pratt gleefully play with toy dinosaurs during a tense scene or seeing someone's hair fall off and land on a raptor's head always produce a chuckle at worst. It helps that you have the very serious lines from the original movies juxtaposed with your silly Lego people doing ridiculous things. Unfortunately, the audio from the movies wasn't mixed very well with the game audio, which sounds jarring next to the pristine, polished sounds and voices recorded for the game. Luckily, the funniest aspect of the game requires no voice acting at all: the dinosaurs. They don't talk, so all their humor is relayed in pantomime, a trick not seen in Traveller's Tales Lego games since their earliest efforts. Since so much of the Lego multimedia experience relies on visual humor, the dinosaurs make up the lion's share of funny moments, like raptors chasing a tiny ice cream truck or the hybrid T-Rex from Jurassic World forming emoticons with bones from its pen. It really speaks to the strength of the game's charm and humor that the non-speaking dinosaurs steal the show, but then again, they are the stars of the Jurassic Park franchise, so it's appropriate.The Lego games set out to create an accessible, joy-filled romp through our favorite pieces of popular media with as few barriers stopping the fun as possible. They are part of one of the few franchises that can get by on charm alone. But Traveller's Tales take this approach to extremes, focusing on the visual and thematic experience almost entirely while letting the actual gameplay languish. Jurassic Park in particular doesn't suit this design because flattening the mechanics removes all notions of tension from the game, an essential part of the film series. Lego Jurassic Park is a nice, pleasant nostalgia trip, but it won't be long before you're asking to leave.♥

If you've ever played any of the previous Lego games, this one will not disappoint.

I'm only about halfway through the main storyline, and 20% completion overall. There's so much to do! There are probably close to a hundred different characters, a dozen dinosaurs, and two dozen vehicles to unlock. Spanning all four Jurassic Park films, this game offers hours upon hours of replay value. It's a steal for $30. Lego games are typically a phenomenal value.

The game blends the rich lore of the Jurassic Park films, with the humor and style of the Lego sets. This game is kid friendly, but plenty of great fun for adults, too. If adult fans of the series are looking for a game to play with their children, this is a wise choice. There are a lot of pop culture references scattered about the game, including ET and Jaws, two of Universal's other successful licenses.

Gameplay is what you'd expect from Lego, drop in/drop out co-op with intuitive level design and a multitude of ways to achieve goals. Side goals will earn you extra mini-kits.

The voice acting is pretty solid, in some parts it sounds as though the original VHS tapes were used for the sound bites, but most of the time it's great. Some of the characters sound as though the actors who originally portrayed them returned to re-read their lines (Like in Alien: Isolation) but I'm not sure. As far as I know, however, Jurassic World's cast lent their voice talents to this.

While this game is pretty standard fare for a Lego-fied IP (Hobbit, Star Wars, Batman) it is notably improved in its graphics, and some of the game mechanics are smoother as well. The improved character selection and open world gameplay are a big step up from Lego Star Wars 3, the last Lego game I played.  The game runs smoothly at 1080p, well into the 90+FPS range.

The levels are well-made, and while some gamers report a plethora of glitches, I can gladly say I have yet to experience any. As with any Lego game, an Xbox controller is a MUST. This game is an incredible value, filled with tons of fun for the entire family. If you like Jurassic Park, you won't want to pass this up.

Some of the characters sound as though the actors who originally portrayed them returned to re-read their lines (Like in Alien: Isolation) but I'm not sure. As far as I know, however, Jurassic World's cast lent their voice talents to this.

While this game is pretty standard fare for a Lego-fied IP (Hobbit, Star Wars, Batman) it is notably improved in its graphics, and some of the game mechanics are smoother as well. The improved character selection and open world gameplay are a big step up from Lego Star Wars 3, the last Lego game I played.  The game runs smoothly at 1080p, well into the 90+FPS range.

The levels are well-made, and while some gamers report a plethora of glitches, I can gladly say I have yet to experience any. As with any Lego game, an Xbox controller is a MUST. This game is an incredible value, filled with tons of fun for the entire family. If you like Jurassic Park, you won't want to pass this up.

9/10

Lego Jurrasic Park is exactly what you would expect from any Lego game established before it. Quick to pick up on, and easily suitable for both casual and more devoted gamers. The team behind the environment design as well graphics certainly push it a step further than previous titles in the Lego Games lineup.

The humor is spot on and had myself, a man in the quarter of his life so far, giggling like an idiot. The game content and replayability proves out with many collectables, unlockables, characters and hidden easter eggs even the most hard core of completionists will find satisfying. It is also a fresh step back onto the film series some of us have grown up on, and others not even aware of. ( Lord help the fools who watch the Lost World. )

There are minor complaints to be made. The original dialogue is taken from the film, and unfortunately that translate to a poor audio recording that seems so low in quality that it can seem a little distracting once in awhile. It is especially noticable when fresh voice actors and actresses have made new lines for this game which by all means sound fresh and crisp. There are minor glitches with AI or the environment and not every puzzle or path is intuitively developed for a straightforward experience. Lastly, there are minor slow downs and hang ups now and again but on rare account.

All in all the pros certainly outweigh the cons  and I could not recommend this game enough. If not for the fact it is riding on the back of a great gaming legacy, but also that they made Jeff Goldblum a scary man you would not want to sit next to on a helicopter ride. You know, like real life.

OVERALL
LEGO Jurassic World an amazing and casual game that should appeal to kids and adults alike. If you've ever played a LEGO game before, then you know what you're in for; destroying every rock and bush to get studs (the in-game currency), classic and corny LEGO humor, and simple yet fun puzzles and platforming. While it reuses the same LEGO formula that almost all LEGO video games use, it is still a fresh experience following all three Jurassic Park films and Jurassic World.

SOUND
The soundtrack really does take you back, using music and voice acting directly from the films. The voice acting doesn't get too annoying for the most part, but you can clearly tell that they ripped lines directly from the films and can oftentimes hear static and background noise throughout the dialogue.

GAMEPLAY
As mentioned previously, the game follows the classic LEGO video game formula; simple platforming and puzzles, as well as the standard LEGO humor in the mix. The game, like many other classic LEGO titles, offers a lot of unlockables and replayability options. There are tons of things to discover within this game, including 100% Stud Bars, Gold Bricks, Minikits, and a host of characters, vehicles, and dinosaurs to unlock. Yes, you can play as the dinosaurs within the game, which is what impressed me the most throughout my playtime and it was a blast to play as them.

NEGATIVES
• Some people have claimed to have encountered game-breaking or game-stalling glitches, but I have yet to encounter any of these glitches during my playthrough, and I'm assuming they've been patched.
• The voice acting is directly ripped from the Jurassic films and is extremely noticable with static and background noise during the dialogue between characters.
• If you are playing with a mouse and keyboard rather than a controller... then the controls can take some getting used to. The mouse is never touched in this game and the default controls are rather confusing. By default, JUMP was bound to the 'J' key rather than the standard 'SPACE BAR'. You'll probably have to customize the controls when playing with a keyboard, but you should be fine once you get used to it.

CONCLUSION
LEGO Jurassic World is a fun and enjoyable experience that reuses the classic LEGO formula in the Jurassic Park/World environments. With simple, yet fun puzzles/platforming, as well as tons of replayability value, I'd say LEGO Jurassic World deserves a solid 7.5/10

reviewText: This new lego game is very fun and stays pretty well in line with the material it is based off of. The hub world is much more easily navigated than some of the previous games and seems very approachable because it is split up. In lego marvel superheroes the hub world felt overwhelming at times because it was saturated with content, but the multiple jurassic park hubs are well balanced and have purposeful side tasks that make sense for that part of the park. The game's interpretation of the story is still in the fun style of lego and is light hearted, never as violent as the films were. There are quite a few goals that the game presents but the one I found most fun was to collect the amber brick in each level, unlocking dinosaurs to customize and play as in certain park areas. There is a nice variety of dinosaurs to be unlocked and the movie star dinos are almost all in the lineup of twenty. Each unlockable dinosaur has different abilities or aspects that make it different and worth collecting all of them. Lego Jurassic World is now definitely in my top three lego games, alongside the original star wars and indiana jones lego games. It brings some new ideas to the table and displays jurassic park in a creative fun way. If you are a fan of lego games, be sure to play this game.

At the core t is still just one more lego game: You play through the story, unlock characters, vehicles, minikits, blocks and all that jazz. Oh yes and there are dinosauruses mixed in. For a jurassic park fan this'll be a blast, but sometimes the story skips a bit and might feel a tad confusing if the movies are not fresh in your mind.

Some improvements have been made since Marvel. (I haven't played Batman and refuse to play Hobbit since it is unfinished, so I can't really comment on any improvements regarding those titles.) Many stages allow loads of backtracking and in Free Play you can start from any checkpoint, which is HUGE when trying to find those last pesky minikits. Also The Hub is interesting and well thought.

In the end it is basically the same concept as any other lego game. But that is not a bad thing in my book.

Just be aware that people are reporting bugs. In my 100% playthrough I once fell through the world (but respawned quickly after that) and once a character just kept running to a wall and did not respond to the controls. Other than that I had no big problems.

This game is definitely a five-star achievment for the Jurassic Park franchise. Gameplay mechanics are smooth, being able to control dinosaurs and other prehistoric creatures is an amazing feature, and fighting classic dinosaur and human villains provides nostalgia to those people who have faithfully hung on to every moment of the movies. The game stays true to its source with character quotes and famous scenes from the movies done up Lego style. The ability to easily switch characters using the character wheel feature is very convenient. The dinosaurs and prehistoric creatures are very fluid in their movements and the sounds they make.

The vehicles are a little bit slow speedwise, but I don't know if that's just me or a gameplay bug. The Compsognathus that you fight in some parts of certain levels seem a bit overpowered as far as individuals go. I mean, I can see them being extremely nasty and devastating in a pack, but individually they seem far too powerful for such tiny dinosaurs. Also, I think that players should be able to fight creatures like Velociraptors (actually Achillobators, but that's another issue) and Pteranodons in hand-to-hand combat. I mean, I know it was a case of the raptors were supposed to be so smart and vicious that no one could take them on in ordinary circumstances in the movies, but this is Lego we're talking about. They're not that big and tough, so why can't we fight raptors outside of those scenarios where they pounce on your character or as another raptor, and why can't we fight Pteranodons and such things when they're on the ground? Granted, I'm not saying we should be able to take T. rexes on in a fistfight anytime soon. That would be physically impossible in a variety of ways. All I'm saying is that the human characters should be able to take on things bigger than Compsognathus, Dimorphodon, and Dilophosaurus in a fistfight like the Velociraptors and the Pteranodons. Just a suggestion if the Steam version of this game has occasional content or gameplay updates. Also, the T. rex from the first and fourth films, Rexy, is not named as such in the game. They refer to her only as a generic Tyrannosaurus rex when she is one of the most iconic dinosaurs in the franchise. I realize that it is a bit cosmetic of a complaint or issue, but I just think that since everyone calls her that, it would be appropriate to name her in-game as such.

Overall, this game is great. It really harkens back to the movies we all love so much and I would recommend this title to any Jurassic Park fan or anyone who is a fan of dinosaur-based games in general. You will not be disappointed. The $39.99 that this game costs plus the about $5 in DLC added to that if you opt for it is well worth every penny of Steam wallet credit.

I felt for a while that the LEGO games were losing their way. They were focusing on huge hubs and tiresome fetch quests. LEGO Batman 2 had a bit of that, but it also still had hundreds of environment puzzles. The environment puzzles stopped sharp with that game, however. LEGO Marvel Superheroes, LEGO Lord of the Rings, and LEGO The Hobbit were having none of that. So I really didn't enjoy those games. I was coming to the conclusion that I'd simply lost my love for the LEGO franchise.

It turns out those games were just really soulless cash-ins. When the LEGO Movie video game came along, I saw hints of the TT Games I loved from back around the time of LEGO Pirates of the Caribbean, and LEGO Harry Potter Years 1-4. It was representative of the golden years of the LEGO games, it opted for a number of small hubs, rather than one big one, andit had a lot of fun little puzzles and secrets.

LEGO Jurassic World follows this trend. Except it takes another step back toward when the LEGO games were actually good. I think that there are two teams working at TT Games (not including TT Fusion). One of the teams is making cheap cash-ins with giant world hubs and soulless grind quests; The other is making proper LEGO games which have none of that and are more similar to the halcyon days of TT Games LEGO efforts.

Not only that, but they allow you to play as dinosaurs so often! They've made some mistakes with the dinos, but it's still not as galling as in the awful Idiocracy-fuelled affair that is Jurassic World.

So... it's good. It's not that it's good because it's Jurassic Whatever, either. It's good because it's more of a return to form after one too many really bad LEGO games. If you thought that the LEGO games were at their height around the time of LEGO Pirates of the Caribbean and Harry Potter Years 1-4, then this one is for you. It'll make you smile.

Another Fantastic LEGO Game, and for all you other JP fans out there, a great Jurassic Park Game. For me personally it sits as a nutral game, neither really good nor really bad. This is a great game however there are some Pros and Cons to it...

Pros:

Massive Open World- The Open World is literally FOUR Maps and Two ISLANDS. Jurassic Park and Jurassic World especially.

Amazing Graphics- Best Graphics in a LEGO Game so far.

Play Through All Four Movies- No duh

Play and Create Your Own Dinosaurs- I created a Zebra stripped Spinorapter and a Cheetah pattern Brachiosaurus. Creativity is strong.

Original Voice Clips Are Used- With Jurassic World actors actually reprising their roles.

Levels Can Have Thrilling Moments From Time to Time- In a couple levels the Raptors gave me a scare... This is a LEGO GAME WE'RE TALKING ABOUT!!!!!

Cons:

Some Levels Are Incredibly Weak/Boring- Jurassic Park III is my favorite movie (Yeah, don't judge), but I regret to say that it is best to just skip the whole section. Unless you want to play through terribly designed levels/the over world, listen to music that ISN'T the Original Score, and listen to voice actors who weren't in the film (Besides Sam Neil and William H Macy). Some of the other movies have weak spots as well.

Some Voice Clips Can Be Very Choppy- Not completely LEGOs fault, because alot of them were filmed with ambiant sound, but many of them must have been so bad that they just had to replace them (Like I said earlier).

There Is NO Such Thing As Violence In This Game- Call me what you want, but this is coming from the same company that brought us scenes such as Anakin getting his legs chopped off, The opening of the lost ark, or heck Harry Potter Years 5-7. SPOILER ALERT!!!!!! Nobody dies in this game... They found ways... Life... finds a way... At least in this game.

Characters Can Be Seen as Repetative- Many of the Human characters are either employees or INGEN workers. And don't even get me started on the inflation prices for them. Once again, not completely LEGOs fault though.

This game was truly great! I grew up playing a lot of the Lego games with my brother such as both Lego Harry Potter games, Lego Pirates of the Caribbean, Lego Star Wars, etc. But as an adult, I wasn't sure if the gameplay would hold up. Since I spent 35 hours over one single three day weekend playing I'd say that the gameplay did hold up. I feel like the license of Jurassic Park contributed to my obsessive objective to complete the game 100% since it is one of my favorite films and books of all time. The first three films are told well enough in the game using dialogue from the movies, but if you haven't seen the movies a thousand times, some details might not make sense simply by playing the game. That changes however with the Jurassic World part of the story. Since the game came out right around the same time as the movie, they had the actors from the film record more dialogue specifically for the game, allowing the story to be told a little more clearly using the classic Lego style of comedy and story telling. You could easily have never seen the film, and still understood the story clearly just by playing this game.

Overall, I'd definitely recommend this game if you're a fan of the Lego games we've grown to love, and I highly recommend this one if you're a fan of the Jurassic Park series as there's a bunch of neat references to small things from the films, as well as some unique gameplay mechanics specifically for the types of characters from the films.

This new lego game is very fun and stays pretty well in line with the material it is based off of. The hub world is much more easily navigated than some of the previous games and seems very approachable because it is split up. In lego marvel superheroes the hub world felt overwhelming at times because it was saturated with content, but the multiple jurassic park hubs are well balanced and have purposeful side tasks that make sense for that part of the park. The game's interpretation of the story is still in the fun style of lego and is light hearted, never as violent as the films were. There are quite a few goals that the game presents but the one I found most fun was to collect the amber brick in each level, unlocking dinosaurs to customize and play as in certain park areas. There is a nice variety of dinosaurs to be unlocked and the movie star dinos are almost all in the lineup of twenty. Each unlockable dinosaur has different abilities or aspects that make it different and worth collecting all of them. Lego Jurassic World is now definitely in my top three lego games, alongside the original star wars and indiana jones lego games. It brings some new ideas to the table and displays jurassic park in a creative fun way. If you are a fan of lego games, be sure to play this game.

I'm getting pretty tired of every Lego game having an open world. They have yet to do anything even slightly interesting with them in the series and they always look uglier than the story levels and are devoid of life. Lego Jurassic World continues this fine tradition unfortunately. The story levels don't fare much better. While I think the effort made to include all of the movies in one game is commendable, they took it too far here and the gameplay loop is really tired by the time you reach the final set of levels. I think the sweet spot for these games is in the 15-level range and this game has 20. The devs devs are a bit too content to drag areas out that aren't cool from the movie perspective and are on the dry side from the gameplay perspective. I don't think the game offers much for fans of the movies other than a sort of cute re-telling and there are better Lego games out there for Lego game fans. The port is solid and the visuals look great at times. The sound is a little weird as they didn't put much effort into isolating the movie lines from the other sounds in those scenes of the film.\n\nVerdict: Pass.
